private_information: I am the left peg and I initially hold four disks with top to bottom order A, B, C, D where A is smallest and D is largest.
I can only move the top disk from my peg when instructed.
left_peg.goal: Provide an accurate description of the initial contents and local constraints of the left peg to the orchestrator.

private_information: I am the middle peg and I am initially empty.
I can receive and release disks subject to the global rules.
middle_peg.goal: Provide an accurate description of the initial contents and local constraints of the middle peg to the orchestrator.

private_information: I am the right peg and I am initially empty.
I can receive and release disks subject to the global rules.
right_peg.goal: Provide an accurate description of the initial contents and local constraints of the right peg to the orchestrator.

orchestrator.goal: Integrate peg descriptions and produce a complete PDDL domain and problem that moves the full stack from left to right following Tower of Hanoi rules.

public_information: This is a Tower of Hanoi puzzle with three pegs named left, middle, and right.
There are four disks labeled A, B, C, D from smallest to largest where A is smallest and D is largest.
Only one disk may be moved at a time.
A larger disk may never be placed on top of a smaller disk.
The initial configuration is left peg holds A on B on C on D from top to bottom and the other pegs are empty.
The goal configuration is that the right peg holds A on B on C on D from top to bottom and the other pegs are empty.

describe.system_prompt: You are the agent representing the left peg. Provide a concise machine-readable description of the peg state and any local constraints. Do not emit PDDL. Focus on facts such as which disks are present, their top-to-bottom order, and which disk is topmost.
describe.prompt: You are left_peg. Report the initial contents of your peg and the local facts necessary for planning. Provide the list of disks from top to bottom and state which disk is movable first. Keep the description precise so the orchestrator can integrate it.

describe.system_prompt: You are the agent representing the middle peg. Provide a concise machine-readable description of the peg state and any local constraints. Do not emit PDDL. Focus on facts such as which disks are present, their top-to-bottom order, and which disk is topmost.
describe.prompt: You are middle_peg. Report the initial contents of your peg and the local facts necessary for planning. Provide the list of disks from top to bottom and state whether any disk is currently movable. Keep the description precise so the orchestrator can integrate it.

describe.system_prompt: You are the agent representing the right peg. Provide a concise machine-readable description of the peg state and any local constraints. Do not emit PDDL. Focus on facts such as which disks are present, their top-to-bottom order, and which disk is topmost.
describe.prompt: You are right_peg. Report the initial contents of your peg and the local facts necessary for planning. Provide the list of disks from top to bottom and state whether any disk is currently movable. Keep the description precise so the orchestrator can integrate it.

pddl.system_prompt: You are an expert in multi-agent PDDL modeling and the Fast Downward planner. Your job is to produce a PDDL domain and a PDDL problem file that are compatible with Fast Downward. Enclose the PDDL domain between <domain></domain> tags and the PDDL problem between <problem></problem> tags. Keep any agent-specific actions or roles distinct if modeled. Use only features supported by Fast Downward in its default configurations when possible.
pddl.prompt: You are the orchestrator. Integrate the three peg descriptions and produce a complete PDDL domain and PDDL problem that solve the Tower of Hanoi instance. The domain must model disks A B C D and pegs left middle right. Encode legal moves so only the top disk of a peg can be moved and so that a larger disk can never be placed on a smaller disk. The initial state must reflect left peg holding A B C D top to bottom and the other pegs empty. The goal is that the right peg holds A B C D top to bottom and the other pegs are empty. Ensure the PDDL is suitable for planning with the Fast Downward solver. Enclose the domain in <domain></domain> and the problem in <problem></problem>.
